properties.name: Ardakty
properties.descript: Ardakty pasture is easily accessible from Eki-Naryn and is regularly used in the summer. Herders pay the municipal pasture committee a fee per animal they bring onto the pasture. The money is used to maintain the roads and bridges connecting the pasture, as well as reforesting the area.

properties.name: The Legend of Ardakty
properties.descript: Many Kyrgyz place names are either a direct reference to a geographic feature or based on a legend. Ardakty is named after an eminent old lady named Ardakty who fell sick in a high pasture. As she was carried down by a camel, she told her relatives to set her down wherever the camel stopped. The camel laid down in Ardakty pasture and the lady passed away, and was buried there.

properties.name: A connection to town
properties.descript: Kyrgyz herders set their yurts close to a road because it allows them to travel back to town for basic household goods like soap. The road also lets travelers and merchants visit the pastures to buy herders' dairy products, serving as an additional source of income. Yurts are almost always located near a source of water and a road for this reason.

properties.name: Ken Tatyr
properties.descript: Ken Tatyr is a remote pasture is not accessible by cars, requiring the use of horses to transport yurts. The yurt is the iconic home of Kyrgyz herders, traditionally made of wood and felt. The act of raising and taking down a yurt requires multiple hands, reaffirming the familial bonds within a herder household.

properties.name: Hand-woven shyrdaks
properties.descript: The abundance of sheep means many traditional products are made of wool. The shyrdak is a hand-stitched carpet cut from multiple layers of felt, adorned by symbols representing ancient shamanistic beliefs. Still done to this day, elders typically teach their children how to craft these beautiful carpets.

properties.name: Moldo Bashy
properties.descript: Traditional Kyrgyz music reflects the open hills. The komuz is a guitar-like stringed instrument that frequently accompanies the singing of the national epic of Manas.

properties.name: Chuko - a throw of bones
properties.descript: Simple games of dexterity and skill are popular among herders of all ages. Chuko uses the anklebones of sheep and has several Central Asian variants, including throwing the bones so that they land on a certain face or throwing one in the air and collecting as many as possible without letting the thrown bone fall on the ground. Among men, kok-buru is an intense game of horseback polo using the carcass of a sheep as the ball.

properties.name: Sary Kyia
properties.descript: Sary Kyia literally translates to a yellow mountain with a pathway for horses. In the mountains, wolves are a stark danger to flocks that roam freely. In response, all herders keep a watch dog to protect their yurts and animals. The Taigan breed is a national icon that considers wolves as prey and has adapted large lungs to make it suited for high mountains. Shepherds offer a symbolic sum of money in exchange for a pup that it will raise into its watch dog.

properties.name: Of horses and gogun
properties.descript: When milking mares, herders yoke their foals to a sticked called "jele", which is Kyrgyz for "spiderweb".  This ensures that the mares will not wander far from their offspring. Each mare is milked near a fire to smoke away gogun, mosquito-like insects whose bite is believed to stop lactation.

properties.name: Taragai
properties.descript: Across the river, Taragai offers easy access to water. Depending on the climate, wealth of the household, and grass conditions, herders will diversify their animals to ensure their survival. For example, horses and sheep are most desired for their meat and milk. In colder climes however, yaks and camels are hardier and are better at defending themselves, removing the need to gather and shelter them each night. These yearly decisions depend on the herder's ability to gauge the coming pasture season and grass conditions.

properties.name: Qurut and dairy
properties.descript: Life on the pastures precludes electricity and fridges. To adapt, herders have learned to produce many different types of dairy products, to ensure nothing goes to waste. These range from qurut, a dried chalky cheese, to kumiz, horse milk that is fermented in a leather container and is considered a national drink.

properties.name: Usengu Kuush and mobile kindergartens
properties.descript: Families would stay the entire summer in Usengu Kuush before returning to their villages. Children that accompany their relatives to the pastures have measurably poorer results in primary school compared to children who stay in town. The Roza Otunbaeva Initiative and Aga Khan Foundation worked to address this by providing training and materials to self-nominated herders. These herders hold pre-school classes for three hours in their yurts, emphasizing play and exploration of local materials. This initiative is enormously popular and has helped bridge the gap for children that spend their summers on the pastures.
